scene.scenelocation: Windsor. A street in front of Page’s house.

stagedir.dir: Enter Justice Shallow, Slender, Sir Hugh Evans.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Here is Got’s plessing, and your friend, and Justice Shallow, and here young Master Slender, that peradventures shall tell you another tale, if matters grow to your likings.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: I am glad to see your worships well. I thank you for my venison, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Master Page, I am glad to see you. Much good do it your good heart! I wish’d your venison better, it was ill kill’d. How doth good Mistress Page?—and I thank you always with my heart, la! With my heart.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir, I thank you.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Sir, I thank you; by yea and no, I do.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: I am glad to see you, good Master Slender.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: How does your fallow greyhound, sir? I heard say he was outrun on Cotsall.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: It could not be judg’d, sir.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: You’ll not confess, you’ll not confess.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: That he will not. ’Tis your fault, ’tis your fault; ’tis a good dog.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: A cur, sir.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Sir! He’s a good dog, and a fair dog—can there be more said? He is good, and fair. Is Sir John Falstaff here?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir, he is within; and I would I could do a good office between you.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: It is spoke as a Christians ought to speak.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: He hath wrong’d me, Master Page.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir, he doth in some sort confess it.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: If it be confess’d, it is not redress’d. Is not that so, Master Page? He hath wrong’d me, indeed he hath, at a word he hath. Believe me, Robert Shallow, esquire, saith he is wrong’d.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Here comes Sir John.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir John Falstaff, Bardolph, Nym, Pistol.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Nay, daughter, carry the wine in, we’ll drink within.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome. Come, we have a hot venison pasty to dinner. Come, gentlemen, I hope we shall drink down all unkindness.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all except Shallow, Slender, and Evans.

scene.line: How now, Simple, where have you been? I must wait on myself, must I? You have not the Book of Riddles about you, have you?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Book of Riddles? Why, did you not lend it to Alice Shortcake upon All-hallowmas last, a fortnight afore Michaelmas?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Come, coz, come, coz, we stay for you. A word with you, coz; marry, this, coz: there is as ’twere a tender, a kind of tender, made afar off by Sir Hugh here. Do you understand me?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Ay, sir, you shall find me reasonable. If it be so, I shall do that that is reason.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Nay, but understand me.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: So I do, sir.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Give ear to his motions: Master Slender, I will description the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Nay, I will do as my cousin Shallow says. I pray you pardon me; he’s a Justice of Peace in his country, simple though I stand here.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: But that is not the question: the question is concerning your marriage.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ay, there’s the point, sir.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Marry, is it; the very point of it—to Mistress Anne Page.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Why, if it be so, I will marry her upon any reasonable demands.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: But can you affection the oman? Let us command to know that of your mouth, or of your lips; for divers philosophers hold that the lips is parcel of the mouth. Therefore precisely, can you carry your good will to the maid?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Cousin Abraham Slender, can you love her?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I hope, sir, I will do as it shall become one that would do reason.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Nay, Got’s lords and his ladies, you must speak possitable, if you can carry her your desires towards her.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: That you must. Will you, upon good dowry, marry her?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I will do a greater thing than that, upon your request, cousin, in any reason.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Nay, conceive me, conceive me, sweet coz; what I do is to pleasure you, coz. Can you love the maid?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I will marry her, sir, at your request; but if there be no great love in the beginning, yet heaven may decrease it upon better acquaintance, when we are married and have more occasion to know one another. I hope, upon familiarity will grow more content. But if you say, “Marry her,” I will marry her; that I am freely dissolv’d, and dissolutely.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: It is a fery discretion answer, save the fall is in the ord “dissolutely.” The ort is (according to our meaning) “resolutely.” His meaning is good.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ay—I think my cousin meant well.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Ay, or else I would I might be hang’d, la!

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Here comes fair Mistress Anne.
Would I were young for your sake, Mistress Anne!

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: The dinner is on the table. My father desires your worships’ company.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: I will wait on him, fair Mistress Anne.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: ’Od’s plessed will! I will not be absence at the grace.

scene.line: A Justice of Peace sometime may be beholding to his friend for a man. I keep but three men and a boy yet, till my mother be dead. But what though? Yet I live like a poor gentleman born.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I may not go in without your worship; they will not sit till you come.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I’ faith, I’ll eat nothing. I thank you as much as though I did.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I pray you, sir, walk in.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I had rather walk here, I thank you. I bruis’d my shin th’ other day with playing at sword and dagger with a master of fence (three veneys for a dish of stew’d prunes) and by my troth, I cannot abide the smell of hot meat since. Why do your dogs bark so? Be there bears i’ th’ town?

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I think there are, sir, I heard them talk’d of.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I love the sport well, but I shall as soon quarrel at it as any man in England. You are afraid if you see the bear loose, are you not?

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Ay indeed, sir.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: That’s meat and drink to me, now. I have seen Sackerson loose twenty times, and have taken him by the chain; but (I warrant you) the women have so cried and shriek’d at it, that it pass’d. But women, indeed, cannot abide ’em, they are very ill-favor’d rough things.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Go your ways, and ask of Doctor Caius’ house which is the way; and there dwells one Mistress Quickly, which is in the manner of his nurse—or his dry nurse—or his cook—or his laundry—his washer and his wringer.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Well, sir.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Nay, it is petter yet. Give her this letter; for it is a oman that altogether’s acquaintance with Mistress Anne Page; and the letter is to desire and require her to solicit your master’s desires to Mistress Anne Page. I pray you be gone. I will make an end of my dinner; there’s pippins and cheese to come.

scene.scenelocation: A room in the Garter Inn.

stagedir.dir: Enter Falstaff, Host, Bardolph, Nym, Pistol, Robin, Falstaff’s page.

scene.line: Let me see thee froth and lime. I am at a word; follow.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: He was gotten in drink. Is not the humor conceited?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am glad I am so acquit of this tinderbox; his thefts were too open; his filching was like an unskillful singer, he kept not time.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: The good humor is to steal at a minute’s rest.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: “Convey,” the wise it call. “Steal”? Foh! A fico for the phrase!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well, sirs, I am almost out at heels.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Why then let kibes ensue.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: There is no remedy; I must cony-catch, I must shift.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Young ravens must have food.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Which of you know Ford of this town?

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: I ken the wight; he is of substance good.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My honest lads, I will tell you what I am about.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Two yards, and more.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No quips now, Pistol! Indeed I am in the waist two yards about; but I am now about no waste; I am about thrift. Briefly—I do mean to make love to Ford’s wife. I spy entertainment in her. She discourses, she carves, she gives the leer of invitation. I can construe the action of her familiar style, and the hardest voice of her behavior (to be English’d rightly) is, “I am Sir John Falstaff’s.”

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: He hath studied her well, and translated her will, out of honesty into English.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: The anchor is deep. Will that humor pass?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Now, the report goes she has all the rule of her husband’s purse. He hath a legend of angels.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: As many devils entertain; and “To her, boy,” say I.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: The humor rises; it is good. Humor me the angels.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I have writ me here a letter to her; and here another to Page’s wife, who even now gave me good eyes too, examin’d my parts with most judicious iliads; sometimes the beam of her view gilded my foot, sometimes my portly belly.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Then did the sun on dunghill shine.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: I thank thee for that humor.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: O, she did so course o’er my exteriors with such a greedy intention, that the appetite of her eye did seem to scorch me up like a burning-glass! Here’s another letter to her. She bears the purse too; she is a region in Guiana, all gold and bounty. I will be cheaters to them both, and they shall be exchequers to me. They shall be my East and West Indies, and I will trade to them both. Go, bear thou this letter to Mistress Page; and thou this to Mistress Ford. We will thrive, lads, we will thrive.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my side wear steel? Then Lucifer take all!

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: I will run no base humor. Here, take the humor-letter; I will keep the havior of reputation.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Let vultures gripe thy guts! For gourd and fullam holds,
And high and low beguiles the rich and poor.
Tester I’ll have in pouch when thou shalt lack,
Base Phrygian Turk!

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: I have operations in my head which be humors of revenge.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Wilt thou revenge?

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: By welkin and her star!

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: With wit or steel?

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: With both the humors, I.
I will discuss the humor of this love to Page.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: And I to Ford shall eke unfold
How Falstaff (varlet vile)
His dove will prove, his gold will hold,
And his soft couch defile.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: My humor shall not cool. I will incense Page to deal with poison; I will possess him with yallowness, for the revolt of mine is dangerous—that is my true humor.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Thou art the Mars of malecontents. I second thee; troop on.

scene.scenelocation: A room in Dr. Caius’s house.
scene.line: I pray thee go to the casement, and see if you can see my master, Master Doctor Caius, coming. If he do, i’ faith, and find any body in the house, here will be an old abusing of God’s patience and the King’s English.

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: I’ll go watch.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Go, and we’ll have a posset for’t soon at night, in faith, at the latter end of a sea-coal fire.

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: Out alas! Here comes my master.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: We shall all be shent. Run in here, good young man; go into this closet. He will not stay long.
What, John Rugby! John! What, John, I say! Go, John, go inquire for my master; I doubt he be not well, that he comes not home.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Vat is you sing? I do not like des toys. Pray you go and vetch me in my closet une boÎte en verd, a box, a green-a box. Do intend vat I speak? A green-a box.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Ay, forsooth, I’ll fetch it you.

I am glad he is so quiet. If he had been throughly mov’d, you should have heard him so loud and so melancholy. But notwithstanding, man, I’ll do you your master what good I can; and the very yea and the no is, the French doctor, my master (I may call him my master, look you, for I keep his house; and I wash, wring, brew, bake, scour, dress meat and drink, make the beds, and do all myself)—

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: ’Tis a great charge to come under one body’s hand.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Are you avis’d o’ that? You shall find it a great charge; and to be up early and down late; but notwithstanding (to tell you in your ear, I would have no words of it) my master himself is in love with Mistress Anne Page; but notwithstanding that, I know Anne’s mind—that’s neither here nor there.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: You jack’nape, give-a this letter to Sir Hugh. By gar, it is a shallenge. I will cut his troat in de park; and I will teach a scurvy jack-a-nape priest to meddle or make— You may be gone; it is not good you tarry here. By gar, I will cut all his two stones; by gar, he shall not have a stone to throw at his dog.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: You shall have Anne—fool’s-head of your own. No, I know Anne’s mind for that. Never a woman in Windsor knows more of Anne’s mind than I do, nor can do more than I do with her, I thank heaven.

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: Who’s within there, ho?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Who’s there, I trow? Come near the house, I pray you.
Truly, an honest gentleman; but Anne loves him not; for I know Anne’s mind as well as another does. Out upon’t! What have I forgot?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: What, have I scap’d love-letters in the holiday-time of my beauty, and am I now a subject for them? Let me see.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Mistress Page, trust me, I was going to your house.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: And trust me, I was coming to you. You look very ill.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Nay, I’ll ne’er believe that; I have to show to the contrary.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Faith, but you do, in my mind.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Well—I do then; yet I say I could show you to the contrary. O Mistress Page, give me some counsel!

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: What’s the matter, woman?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: O woman—if it were not for one trifling respect, I could come to such honor!

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Hang the trifle, woman, take the honor. What is it? Dispense with trifles. What is it?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: If I would but go to hell for an eternal moment or so, I could be knighted.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: What? Thou liest! Sir Alice Ford! These knights will hack, and so thou shouldst not alter the article of thy gentry.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: We burn daylight. Here, read, read; perceive how I might be knighted. I shall think the worse of fat men, as long as I have an eye to make difference of men’s liking: and yet he would not swear; prais’d women’s modesty; and gave such orderly and well-behav’d reproof to all uncomeliness, that I would have sworn his disposition would have gone to the truth of his words; but they do no more adhere and keep place together than the hundred Psalms to the tune of “Green-sleeves.” What tempest, I trow, threw this whale (with so many tuns of oil in his belly) ashore at Windsor? How shall I be reveng’d on him? I think the best way were to entertain him with hope, till the wicked fire of lust have melted him in his own grease. Did you ever hear the like?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Letter for letter; but that the name of Page and Ford differs! To thy great comfort in this mystery of ill opinions, here’s the twin-brother of thy letter; but let thine inherit first, for I protest mine never shall. I warrant he hath a thousand of these letters, writ with blank space for different names (sure, more!); and these are of the second edition. He will print them, out of doubt; for he cares not what he puts into the press, when he would put us two. I had rather be a giantess, and lie under Mount Pelion. Well—I will find you twenty lascivious turtles ere one chaste man.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Why, this is the very same: the very hand; the very words. What doth he think of us?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Nay, I know not; it makes me almost ready to wrangle with mine own honesty. I’ll entertain myself like one that I am not acquainted withal; for sure unless he know some strain in me that I know not myself, he would never have boarded me in this fury.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: “Boarding,” call you it? I’ll be sure to keep him above deck.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: So will I; if he come under my hatches, I’ll never to sea again. Let’s be reveng’d on him: let’s appoint him a meeting, give him a show of comfort in his suit, and lead him on with a fine-baited delay, till he hath pawn’d his horses to mine host of the Garter.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Nay, I will consent to act any villainy against him, that may not sully the chariness of our honesty. O that my husband saw this letter! It would give eternal food to his jealousy.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Why, look where he comes; and my good man too. He’s as far from jealousy as I am from giving him cause, and that (I hope) is an unmeasurable distance.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: You are the happier woman.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Let’s consult together against this greasy knight. Come hither.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Well, I hope it be not so.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Hope is a curtal dog in some affairs. Sir John affects thy wife.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Why, sir, my wife is not young.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: He woos both high and low, both rich and poor,
Both young and old, one with another, Ford.
He loves the gallimaufry, Ford. Perpend.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Love my wife?

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: With liver burning hot. Prevent; or go thou
Like Sir Actaeon he, with Ringwood at thy heels—
O, odious is the name!

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: What name, sir?

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: The horn, I say. Farewell.
Take heed, have open eye, for thieves do foot by night.
Take heed, ere summer comes or cuckoo-birds do sing.
Away, Sir Corporal Nym!
Believe it, Page, he speaks sense.
I will be patient; I will find out this.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: “The humor of it,” quoth ’a! Here’s a fellow frights English out of his wits.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I will seek out Falstaff.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: I never heard such a drawling, affecting rogue.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: If I do find it—well.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: I will not believe such a Cataian, though the priest o’ th’ town commended him for a true man.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: ’Twas a good sensible fellow—well.

stagedir.dir: Mrs. Page and Mrs. Ford come forward.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: How now, Meg?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Whither go you, George, hark you?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: How now, sweet Frank, why art thou melancholy?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I melancholy? I am not melancholy. Get you home; go.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Faith, thou hast some crotchets in thy head now. Will you go, Mistress Page?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Have with you. You’ll come to dinner, George?
Look who comes yonder. She shall be our messenger to this paltry knight.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Trust me, I thought on her. She’ll fit it.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: How now, Master Ford?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: You heard what this knave told me, did you not?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Yes, and you heard what the other told me?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Do you think there is truth in them?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Hang ’em, slaves! I do not think the knight would offer it; but these that accuse him in his intent towards our wives are a yoke of his discarded men—very rogues, now they be out of service.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Were they his men?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Marry, were they.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I like it never the better for that. Does he lie at the Garter?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Ay, marry, does he. If he should intend this voyage toward my wife, I would turn her loose to him; and what he gets more of her than sharp words, let it lie on my head.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I do not misdoubt my wife; but I would be loath to turn them together. A man may be too confident. I would have nothing lie on my head. I cannot be thus satisfied.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: I follow, mine host, I follow. Good even and twenty, good Master Page! Master Page, will you go with us? We have sport in hand.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Tell him, Cavaleiro Justice; tell him, bully-rook.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Sir, there is a fray to be fought between Sir Hugh the Welsh priest and Caius the French doctor.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Good mine host o’ th’ Garter, a word with you.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: What say’st thou, my bully-rook?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Though Page be a secure fool, and stands so firmly on his wife’s frailty, yet I cannot put off my opinion so easily. She was in his company at Page’s house; and what they made there, I know not. Well, I will look further into’t, and I have a disguise to sound Falstaff. If I find her honest, I lose not my labor; if she be otherwise, ’tis labor well bestow’d.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: I will retort the sum in equipage.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I will not lend thee a penny.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Why then the world’s mine oyster,
Which I with sword will open.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Not a penny. I have been content, sir, you should lay my countenance to pawn. I have grated upon my good friends for three reprieves for you and your coach-fellow Nym; or else you had look’d through the grate, like a geminy of baboons. I am damn’d in hell for swearing to gentlemen my friends, you were good soldiers and tall fellows; and when Mistress Bridget lost the handle of her fan, I took’t upon mine honor thou hadst it not.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Didst not thou share? Hadst thou not fifteen pence?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Reason, you rogue, reason; think’st thou I’ll endanger my soul gratis? At a word, hang no more about me, I am no gibbet for you. Go—a short knife and a throng!—to your manor of Pickt-hatch! Go. You’ll not bear a letter for me, you rogue? You stand upon your honor! Why, thou unconfinable baseness, it is as much as I can do to keep the terms of my honor precise. I, I, I myself sometimes, leaving the fear of God on the left hand, and hiding mine honor in my necessity, am fain to shuffle, to hedge, and to lurch; and yet you, rogue, will ensconce your rags, your cat-a-mountain looks, your red-lattice phrases, and your bold-beating oaths, under the shelter of your honor! You will not do it? You!

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: I do relent. What would thou more of man?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Give your worship good morrow.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Good morrow, goodwife.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Not so, and’t please your worship.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Good maid then.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: I’ll be sworn,
As my mother was the first hour I was born.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I do believe the swearer. What with me?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Shall I vouchsafe your worship a word or two?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Two thousand, fair woman, and I’ll vouchsafe thee the hearing.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: There is one Mistress Ford, sir—I pray come a little nearer this ways. I myself dwell with Master Doctor Caius—

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well, on. Mistress Ford, you say—

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Your worship says very true. I pray your worship come a little nearer this ways.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I warrant thee, nobody hears—mine own people, mine own people.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Are they so? God bless them and make them his servants!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well; Mistress Ford, what of her?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Why, sir, she’s a good creature. Lord, Lord, your worship’s a wanton! Well—heaven forgive you, and all of us, I pray—

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Mistress Ford; come, Mistress Ford—

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Marry, this is the short and the long of it: you have brought her into such a canaries as ’tis wonderful. The best courtier of them all (when the court lay at Windsor) could never have brought her to such a canary; yet there has been knights, and lords, and gentlemen, with their coaches; I warrant you, coach after coach, letter after letter, gift after gift; smelling so sweetly, all musk, and so rushling, I warrant you, in silk and gold, and in such alligant terms, and in such wine and sugar of the best, and the fairest, that would have won any woman’s heart; and I warrant you, they could never get an eye-wink of her. I had myself twenty angels given me this morning, but I defy all angels (in any such sort, as they say) but in the way of honesty; and I warrant you, they could never get her so much as sip on a cup with the proudest of them all, and yet there has been earls, nay (which is more) pensioners, but I warrant you all is one with her.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: But what says she to me? Be brief, my good she-Mercury.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Marry, she hath receiv’d your letter—for the which she thanks you a thousand times—and she gives you to notify that her husband will be absence from his house between ten and eleven.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Ten and eleven?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Ay, forsooth; and then you may come and see the picture, she says, that you wot of. Master Ford her husband will be from home. Alas, the sweet woman leads an ill life with him. He’s a very jealousy man. She leads a very frampold life with him, good heart.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Ten and eleven. Woman, commend me to her, I will not fail her.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Why, you say well. But I have another messenger to your worship. Mistress Page hath her hearty commendations to you too; and let me tell you in your ear, she’s as fartuous a civil modest wife, and one (I tell you) that will not miss you morning nor evening prayer, as any is in Windsor, whoe’er be the other; and she bade me tell your worship that her husband is seldom from home, but she hopes there will come a time. I never knew a woman so dote upon a man; surely I think you have charms, la; yes, in truth.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Not I, I assure thee. Setting the attraction of my good parts aside, I have no other charms.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Blessing on your heart for’t!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: But I pray thee tell me this: has Ford’s wife and Page’s wife acquainted each other how they love me?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: That were a jest indeed! They have not so little grace, I hope. That were a trick indeed! But Mistress Page would desire you to send her your little page, of all loves. Her husband has a marvellous infection to the little page; and truly Master Page is an honest man. Never a wife in Windsor leads a better life than she does: do what she will, say what she will, take all, pay all, go to bed when she list, rise when she list, all is as she will; and truly she deserves it, for if there be a kind woman in Windsor, she is one. You must send her your page, no remedy.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Why, I will.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Nay, but do so then, and look you, he may come and go between you both; and in any case have a nay-word, that you may know one another’s mind, and the boy never need to understand any thing; for ’tis not good that children should know any wickedness. Old folks, you know, have discretion, as they say, and know the world.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Fare thee well, commend me to them both. There’s my purse, I am yet thy debtor. Boy, go along with this woman.
This punk is one of Cupid’s carriers.
Clap on more sails, pursue; up with your fights;
Give fire! She is my prize, or ocean whelm them all!

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Sir John, there’s one Master Brook below would fain speak with you, and be acquainted with you; and hath sent your worship a morning’s draught of sack.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Brook is his name?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Ay, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Call him in.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: God save you, sir!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: And you, sir! Would you speak with me?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I make bold, to press with so little preparation upon you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: You’re welcome. What’s your will? Give us leave, drawer.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: What a damn’d Epicurean rascal is this! My heart is ready to crack with impatience. Who says this is improvident jealousy? My wife hath sent to him, the hour is fix’d, the match is made. Would any man have thought this? See the hell of having a false woman! My bed shall be abus’d, my coffers ransack’d, my reputation gnawn at, and I shall not only receive this villainous wrong, but stand under the adoption of abominable terms, and by him that does me this wrong. Terms! Names! Amaimon sounds well; Lucifer, well; Barbason, well; yet they are devils’ additions, the names of fiends; but Cuckold! Wittol!—Cuckold! The devil himself hath not such a name. Page is an ass, a secure ass; he will trust his wife, he will not be jealous. I will rather trust a Fleming with my butter, Parson Hugh the Welshman with my cheese, an Irishman with my aqua-vitae bottle, or a thief to walk my ambling gelding, than my wife with herself. Then she plots, then she ruminates, then she devises; and what they think in their hearts they may effect, they will break their hearts but they will effect. God be prais’d for my jealousy! Eleven o’ clock the hour. I will prevent this, detect my wife, be reveng’d on Falstaff, and laugh at Page. I will about it; better three hours too soon than a minute too late. Fie, fie, fie! Cuckold, cuckold, cuckold!

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Jack Rugby!

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: Sir?

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Vat is the clock, Jack?

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: ’Tis past the hour, sir, that Sir Hugh promis’d to meet.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, he has save his soul, dat he is no come; he has pray his Pible well, dat he is no come. By gar, Jack Rugby, he is dead already, if he be come.

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: He is wise, sir; he knew your worship would kill him if he came.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, de herring is no dead so as I vill kill him. Take your rapier, Jack, I vill tell you how I vill kill him.

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: Alas, sir, I cannot fence.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Villainy, take your rapier.

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: Forbear; here’s company.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: He is there. See what humor he is in; and I will bring the doctor about by the fields. Will it do well?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: We will do it.

speech.speaker: ALL PAGE. AND SHAL. AND SLEN.
speech.line: Adieu, good Master Doctor.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all but the Host, Caius, and Rugby.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: I pray you now, good Master Slender’s servingman, and friend Simple by your name, which way have you look’d for Master Caius, that calls himself Doctor of Physic?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Marry, sir, the pittie-ward, the park-ward—every way; Old Windsor way, and every way but the town way.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: I most fehemently desire you you will also look that way.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: I will, sir.
“To shallow rivers, to whose falls
Melodious birds sings madrigals;
There will we make our peds of roses,
And a thousand fragrant posies.
To shallow—”
Mercy on me! I have a great dispositions to cry.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Yonder he is coming, this way, Sir Hugh.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: He’s welcome.
Ah, sweet Anne Page!

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: God save you, good Sir Hugh!

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: God pless you from his mercy sake, all of you!

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: What? The sword and the word? Do you study them both, Master Parson?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: And youthful still, in your doublet and hose, this raw rheumatic day?

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: There is reasons and causes for it.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: We are come to you to do a good office, Master Parson.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Fery well; what is it?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Yonder is a most reverend gentleman, who, belike having receiv’d wrong by some person, is at most odds with his own gravity and patience that ever you saw.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: I have liv’d fourscore years and upward; I never heard a man of his place, gravity, and learning, so wide of his own respect.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: What is he?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: I think you know him: Master Doctor Caius, the renown’d French physician.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Got’s will, and his passion of my heart! I had as lief you would tell me of a mess of porridge.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: He has no more knowledge in Hibocrates and Galen—and he is a knave besides, a cowardly knave as you would desires to be acquainted withal.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: I warrant you, he’s the man should fight with him.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: O sweet Anne Page!

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Nay, good Master Parson, keep in your weapon.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: So do you, good Master Doctor.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Disarm them, and let them question. Let them keep their limbs whole and hack our English.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: I pray you let-a me speak a word with your ear. Vherefore vill you not meet-a me?

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Pray you use your patience in good time.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, you are de coward, de Jack dog, John ape.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Pray you let us not be laughing-stocks to other men’s humors. I desire you in friendship, and I will one way or other make you amends.
I will knog your urinals about your knave’s cogscomb for missing your meetings and appointments.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Diable! Jack Rugby—mine host de Jarteer—have I not stay for him to kill him? Have I not, at de place I did appoint?

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: As I am a Christians-soul, now look you; this is the place appointed. I’ll be judgment by mine host of the Garter.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Peace, I say, Gallia and Gaul, French and Welsh, soul-curer and body-curer!

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Ay, dat is very good, excellant.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Peace, I say! Hear mine host of the Garter. Am I politic? Am I subtle? Am I a Machiavel? Shall I lose my doctor? No, he gives me the potions and the motions. Shall I lose my parson? My priest? My Sir Hugh? No, he gives me the proverbs and the no-verbs. Give me thy hand, terrestial; so. Give me thy hand, celestial; so. Boys of art, I have deceiv’d you both; I have directed you to wrong places. Your hearts are mighty, your skins are whole, and let burnt sack be the issue. Come, lay their swords to pawn. Follow me, lads of peace; follow, follow, follow.
O sweet Anne Page!

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Nay, keep your way, little gallant; you were wont to be a follower, but now you are a leader. Whether had you rather lead mine eyes, or eye your master’s heels?

speech.speaker: ROB.
speech.line: I had rather, forsooth, go before you like a man than follow him like a dwarf.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: O, you are a flattering boy, now I see you’ll be a courtier.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Has Page any brains? Hath he any eyes? Hath he any thinking? Sure they sleep, he hath no use of them. Why, this boy will carry a letter twenty mile, as easy as a cannon will shoot point-blank twelve score. He pieces out his wive’s inclination; he gives her folly motion and advantage; and now she’s going to my wife, and Falstaff’s boy with her. A man may hear this show’r sing in the wind. And Falstaff’s boy with her! Good plots, they are laid, and our revolted wives share damnation together. Well, I will take him, then torture my wife, pluck the borrow’d veil of modesty from the so-seeming Mistress Page, divulge Page himself for a secure and willful Actaeon; and to these violent proceedings all my neighbors shall cry aim.

The clock gives me my cue, and my assurance bids me search—there I shall find Falstaff. I shall be rather prais’d for this than mock’d; for it is as positive as the earth is firm that Falstaff is there. I will go.

stagedir.dir: Enter Page, Shallow, Slender, Host, Evans, Caius, Rugby.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Go home, John Rugby, I come anon.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I think I shall drink in pipe-wine first with him; I’ll make him dance.—Will you go, gentles?

speech.speaker: PAGE., EVANS. AND CAIUS
speech.line: Have with you to see this monster.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Come, come, come.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Here, set it down.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Give your men the charge, we must be brief.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Marry, as I told you before, John and Robert, be ready here hard by in the brew-house, and when I suddenly call you, come forth, and (without any pause or staggering) take this basket on your shoulders. That done, trudge with it in all haste, and carry it among the whitsters in Datchet-mead, and there empty it in the muddy ditch close by the Thames side.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: You will do it?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: I ha’ told them over and over, they lack no direction. Be gone, and come when you are call’d.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: How now, my eyas-musket, what news with you?

speech.speaker: ROB.
speech.line: My master, Sir John, is come in at your back door, Mistress Ford, and requests your company.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: You little Jack-a-Lent, have you been true to us?

speech.speaker: ROB.
speech.line: Ay, I’ll be sworn. My master knows not of your being here, and hath threat’ned to put me into everlasting liberty if I tell you of it; for he swears he’ll turn me away.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Thou’rt a good boy. This secrecy of thine shall be a tailor to thee, and shall make thee a new doublet and hose. I’ll go hide me.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Do so. Go tell thy master I am alone.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Go to then. We’ll use this unwholesome humidity, this gross wat’ry pumpion. We’ll teach him to know turtles from jays.

speech.speaker: ROB.
speech.line: Mistress Ford, Mistress Ford! Here’s Mistress Page at the door, sweating, and blowing, and looking wildly, and would needs speak with you presently.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: She shall not see me, I will ensconce me behind the arras.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Pray you do so, she’s a very tattling woman.
Are these your letters, knight?

speech.speaker: FAL.
FORD.
speech.line: Pray you come near. If I suspect without cause, why then make sport at me, then let me be your jest, I deserve it. How now? Whither bear you this?

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: To the laundress, forsooth.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Why, what have you to do whither they bear it? You were best meddle with buck-washing.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Buck! I would I could wash myself of the buck! Buck, buck, buck! Ay, buck! I warrant you, buck, and of the season too, it shall appear.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: This is fery fantastical humors and jealousies.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, ’tis no the fashion of France; it is not jealous in France.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Nay, follow him, gentlemen, see the issue of his search.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I cannot find him. May be the knave bragg’d of that he could not compass.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Heard you that?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: You use me well, Master Ford, do you?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Ay, I do so.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Heaven make you better than your thoughts!

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Amen!

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: You do yourself mighty wrong, Master Ford.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Ay, ay; I must bear it.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: If there be any pody in the house, and in the chambers, and in the coffers, and in the presses, heaven forgive my sins at the day of judgment!

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Be-gar, nor I too; there is no-bodies.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Fie, fie, Master Ford, are you not asham’d? What spirit, what devil suggests this imagination? I would not ha’ your distemper in this kind for the wealth of Windsor Castle.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: ’Tis my fault, Master Page. I suffer for it.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: You suffer for a pad conscience. Your wife is as honest a omans as I will desires among five thousand, and five hundred too.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, I see ’tis an honest woman.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Well, I promis’d you a dinner. Come, come, walk in the park. I pray you pardon me; I will hereafter make known to you why I have done this. Come, wife, come, Mistress Page, I pray you pardon me; pray heartly pardon me.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Let’s go in, gentlemen, but (trust me) we’ll mock him. I do invite you tomorrow morning to my house to breakfast; after, we’ll a-birding together. I have a fine hawk for the bush. Shall it be so?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Any thing.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: If there is one, I shall make two in the company.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: If there be one or two, I shall make-a the turd.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Pray you go, Master Page.

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: I see I cannot get thy father’s love,
Therefore no more turn me to him, sweet Nan.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Alas, how then?

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: Why, thou must be thyself.
He doth object I am too great of birth,
And that my state being gall’d with my expense,
I seek to heal it only by his wealth.
Besides these, other bars he lays before me,
My riots past, my wild societies,
And tells me ’tis a thing impossible
I should love thee but as a property.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: May be he tells you true.

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: No, heaven so speed me in my time to come!
Albeit I will confess thy father’s wealth
Was the first motive that I woo’d thee, Anne;
Yet wooing thee, I found thee of more value
Than stamps in gold, or sums in sealed bags;
And ’tis the very riches of thyself
That now I aim at.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Gentle Master Fenton,
Yet seek my father’s love, still seek it, sir.
If opportunity and humblest suit
Cannot attain it, why then hark you hither!
This is my father’s choice.
O, what a world of vild ill-favor’d faults
Looks handsome in three hundred pounds a year!

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: And how does good Master Fenton? Pray you a word with you.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: She’s coming; to her, coz. O boy, thou hadst a father!

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I had a father, Mistress Anne, my uncle can tell you good jests of him. Pray you, uncle, tell Mistress Anne the jest how my father stole two geese out of a pen, good uncle.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Mistress Anne, my cousin loves you.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Ay, that I do—as well as I love any woman in Gloucestershire.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: He will maintain you like a gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Ay, that I will, come cut and long-tail, under the degree of a squire.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: He will make you a hundred and fifty pounds jointure.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Good Master Shallow, let him woo for himself.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Marry, I thank you for it; I thank you for that good comfort. She calls you, coz. I’ll leave you.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Now, Master Slender—

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Now, good Mistress Anne—

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: What is your will?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: My will? ’Od’s heartlings, that’s a pretty jest indeed! I ne’er made my will yet, I thank heaven. I am not such a sickly creature, I give heaven praise.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I mean, Master Slender, what would you with me?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Truly, for mine own part, I would little or nothing with you. Your father and my uncle hath made motions. If it be my luck, so; if not, happy man be his dole! They can tell you how things go better than I can. You may ask your father, here he comes.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Speak to Mistress Page.

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: Good Mistress Page, for that I love your daughter
In such a righteous fashion as I do,
Perforce, against all checks, rebukes, and manners,
I must advance the colors of my love,
And not retire. Let me have your good will.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Good mother, do not marry me to yond fool.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: I mean it not, I seek you a better husband.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: That’s my master, Master Doctor.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Alas, I had rather be set quick i’ th’ earth,
And bowl’d to death with turnips!

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Come, trouble not yourself. Good Master Fenton,
I will not be your friend nor enemy.
My daughter will I question how she loves you,
And as I find her, so am I affected.
Till then farewell, sir; she must needs go in,
Her father will be angry.

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: Farewell, gentle mistress; farewell, Nan.

A kind heart he hath. A woman would run through fire and water for such a kind heart. But yet I would my master had Mistress Anne; or I would Master Slender had her; or, in sooth, I would Master Fenton had her. I will do what I can for them all three, for so I have promis’d, and I’ll be as good as my word, but speciously for Master Fenton. Well, I must of another errand to Sir John Falstaff from my two mistresses. What a beast am I to slack it!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Bardolph, I say!

Have I liv’d to be carried in a basket like a barrow of butcher’s offal? And to be thrown in the Thames? Well, and I be serv’d such another trick, I’ll have my brains ta’en out and butter’d, and give them to a dog for a new-year’s gift. The rogues slighted me into the river with as little remorse as they would have drown’d a blind bitch’s puppies, fifteen i’ th’ litter; and you may know by my size that I have a kind of alacrity in sinking; and the bottom were as deep as hell, I should down. I had been drown’d, but that the shore was shelvy and shallow—a death that I abhor; for the water swells a man; and what a thing should I have been when I had been swell’d! I should have been a mountain of mummy.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: By your leave; I cry you mercy! Give your worship good morrow.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Take away these chalices. Go, brew me a pottle of sack finely.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: With eggs, sir?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Simple of itself; I’ll no pullet-sperm in my brewage.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I marvel I hear not of Master Brook; he sent me word to stay within. I like his money well. O, here he comes.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Hum! Ha? Is this a vision? Is this a dream? Do I sleep? Master Ford, awake! Awake, Master Ford! There’s a hole made in your best coat, Master Ford. This ’tis to be married! This ’tis to have linen and buck-baskets! Well, I will proclaim myself what I am. I will now take the lecher; he is at my house. He cannot scape me; ’tis impossible he should; he cannot creep into a halfpenny purse, nor into a pepper-box. But lest the devil that guides him should aid him, I will search impossible places. Though what I am I cannot avoid, yet to be what I would not shall not make me tame. If I have horns to make one mad, let the proverb go with me: I’ll be horn-mad.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Is he at Master Ford’s already, think’st thou?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Sure he is by this—or will be presently. But truly he is very courageous mad about his throwing into the water. Mistress Ford desires you to come suddenly.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: I’ll be with her by and by; I’ll but bring my young man here to school.
Get you home, boy. Come, we stay too long.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Truly, I am so glad you have nobody here.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Why, woman, your husband is in his old lines again. He so takes on yonder with my husband; so rails against all married mankind; so curses all Eve’s daughters, of what complexion soever; and so buffets himself on the forehead, crying, “Peer out, peer out!” , that any madness I ever yet beheld seem’d but tameness, civility, and patience to this his distemper he is in now. I am glad the fat knight is not here.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Why, does he talk of him?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Of none but him, and swears he was carried out, the last time he search’d for him, in a basket; protests to my husband he is now here, and hath drawn him and the rest of their company from their sport, to make another experiment of his suspicion. But I am glad the knight is not here. Now he shall see his own foolery.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: How near is he, Mistress Page?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Hard by, at street end; he will be here anon.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: I am undone! The knight is here.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Why then you are utterly sham’d, and he’s but a dead man. What a woman are you? Away with him, away with him! Better shame than murder.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Which way should he go? How should I bestow him? Shall I put him into the basket again?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: I would my husband would meet him in this shape. He cannot abide the old woman of Brainford. He swears she’s a witch, forbade her my house, and hath threat’ned to beat her.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Heaven guide him to thy husband’s cudgel; and the devil guide his cudgel afterwards!

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: But is my husband coming?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Ay, in good sadness, is he, and talks of the basket too, howsoever he hath had intelligence.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: We’ll try that; for I’ll appoint my men to carry the basket again, to meet him at the door with it, as they did last time.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Nay, but he’ll be here presently. Let’s go dress him like the witch of Brainford.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: I’ll first direct my men what they shall do with the basket. Go up, I’ll bring linen for him straight.

stagedir.dir: Enter Mistress Ford with two Servants.

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: Come, come, take it up.

speech.speaker: 2. SERV.
speech.line: Pray heaven it be not full of knight again.

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: I hope not, I had lief as bear so much lead.

stagedir.dir: Enter Ford, Page, Caius, Evans, Shallow.

scene.line: Come hither, Mistress Ford, Mistress Ford, the honest woman, the modest wife, the virtuous creature, that hath the jealous fool to her husband! I suspect without cause, mistress, do I?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Heaven be my witness you do, and if you suspect me in any dishonesty.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Well said, brazen-face! Hold it out. Come forth, sirrah!

stagedir.dir: Pulling clothes out of the basket.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: This passes!

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Are you not asham’d? Let the clothes alone.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I shall find you anon.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: ’Tis unreasonable! Will you take up your wive’s clothes? Come away.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Empty the basket, I say!

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Why, man, why?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Master Page, as I am a man, there was one convey’d out of my house yesterday in this basket. Why may not he be there again? In my house I am sure he is. My intelligence is true, my jealousy is reasonable. Pluck me out all the linen.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: If you find a man there, he shall die a flea’s death.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Here’s no man.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: By my fidelity, this is not well, Master Ford; this wrongs you.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Master Ford, you must pray, and not follow the imaginations of your own heart. This is jealousies.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Well, he’s not here I seek for.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: No, nor no where else but in your brain.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Help to search my house this one time. If I find not what I seek, show no color for my extremity; let me forever be your table-sport. Let them say of me, “As jealous as Ford, that search’d a hollow walnut for his wive’s leman.” Satisfy me once more, once more search with me.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: What ho, Mistress Page! Come you and the old woman down; my husband will come into the chamber.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Old woman? What old woman’s that?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Why, it is my maid’s aunt of Brainford.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: A witch, a quean, an old cozening quean! Have I not forbid her my house? She comes of errands, does she? We are simple men, we do not know what’s brought to pass under the profession of fortune-telling. She works by charms, by spells, by th’ figure, and such daub’ry as this is, beyond our element; we know nothing. Come down, you witch, you hag you, come down, I say!

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Nay, good, sweet husband! Good gentlemen, let him not strike the old woman.

stagedir.dir: Enter Falstaff disguised like an old woman, and Mistress Page with him.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Trust me, he beat him most pitifully.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Nay, by th’ mass, that he did not; he beat him most unpitifully, methought.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: I’ll have the cudgel hallow’d and hung o’er the altar; it hath done meritorious service.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: What think you? May we, with the warrant of womanhood and the witness of a good conscience, pursue him with any further revenge?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: The spirit of wantonness is sure scar’d out of him. If the devil have him not in fee-simple, with fine and recovery, he will never, I think, in the way of waste, attempt us again.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Shall we tell our husbands how we have serv’d him?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Yes, by all means; if it be but to scrape the figures out of your husband’s brains. If they can find in their hearts the poor unvirtuous fat knight shall be any further afflicted, we two will still be the ministers.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: I’ll warrant they’ll have him publicly sham’d, and methinks there would be no period to the jest, should he not be publicly sham’d.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Come, to the forge with it, then shape it. I would not have things cool.

scene.scenelocation: A room in the Garter Inn.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: ’Tis one of the best discretions of a oman as ever I did look upon.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: And did he send you both these letters at an instant?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Within a quarter of an hour.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Pardon me, wife, henceforth do what thou wilt.
I rather will suspect the sun with cold
Than thee with wantonness. Now doth thy honor stand,
In him that was of late an heretic,
As firm as faith.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: ’Tis well, ’tis well, no more.
Be not as extreme in submission as in offense;
But let our plot go forward. Let our wives
Yet once again (to make us public sport)
Appoint a meeting with this old fat fellow,
Where we may take him, and disgrace him for it.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: There is no better way than that they spoke of.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: How? To send him word they’ll meet him in the park at midnight? Fie, fie, he’ll never come.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: You say he has been thrown in the rivers, and has been grievously peaten as an old oman. Methinks there should be terrors in him that he should not come; methinks his flesh is punish’d, he shall have no desires.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: So think I too.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Devise but how you’ll use him when he comes,
And let us two devise to bring him thither.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: There is an old tale goes, that Herne the Hunter
(Sometime a keeper here in Windsor forest)
Doth all the winter-time, at still midnight,
Walk round about an oak, with great ragg’d horns,
And there he blasts the tree, and takes the cattle,
And makes milch-kine yield blood, and shakes a chain
In a most hideous and dreadful manner.
You have heard of such a spirit, and well you know
The superstitious idle-headed eld
Receiv’d and did deliver to our age
This tale of Herne the Hunter for a truth.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Why, yet there want not many that do fear
In deep of night to walk by this Herne’s oak.
But what of this?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Marry, this is our device:
That Falstaff at that oak shall meet with us,
Disguis’d like Herne, with huge horns on his head.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Well, let it not be doubted but he’ll come,
And in this shape when you have brought him thither,
What shall be done with him? What is your plot?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: That likewise have we thought upon, and thus:
Nan Page (my daughter) and my little son,
And three or four more of their growth, we’ll dress
Like urchins, ouphes, and fairies, green and white,
With rounds of waxen tapers on their heads,
And rattles in their hands. Upon a sudden,
As Falstaff, she, and I are newly met,
Let them from forth a sawpit rush at once
With some diffused song. Upon their sight,
We two in great amazedness will fly;
Then let them all encircle him about,
And fairy-like to pinch the unclean knight;
And ask him why, that hour of fairy revel,
In their so sacred paths he dares to tread
In shape profane.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: And till he tell the truth,
Let the supposed fairies pinch him sound,
And burn him with their tapers.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: The truth being known,
We’ll all present ourselves; dis-horn the spirit,
And mock him home to Windsor.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: The children must
Be practic’d well to this, or they’ll nev’r do’t.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: I will teach the children their behaviors; and I will be like a jack-an-apes also, to burn the knight with my taber.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: That will be excellent. I’ll go buy them vizards.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: My Nan shall be the queen of all the fairies,
Finely attired in a robe of white.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: That silk will I go buy.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Go, Mistress Ford,
Send Quickly to Sir John, to know his mind.

scene.scenelocation: A room in the Garter Inn.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: There was, mine host, an old fat woman even now with me, but she’s gone.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Pray you, sir, was’t not the wise woman of Brainford?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Ay, marry, was it, mussel-shell, what would you with her?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: My master, sir, my Master Slender, sent to her, seeing her go thorough the streets, to know, sir, whether one Nym, sir, that beguil’d him of a chain, had the chain or no.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I spake with the old woman about it.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: And what says she, I pray, sir?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Marry, she says that the very same man that beguil’d Master Slender of his chain cozen’d him of it.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: I would I could have spoken with the woman herself. I had other things to have spoken with her too from him.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What are they? Let us know.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Ay; come; quick.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: I may not conceal them, sir.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Conceal them, or thou diest.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Why, sir, they were nothing but about Mistress Anne Page, to know if it were my master’s fortune to have her or no.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Tis, ’tis his fortune.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: What, sir?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: To have her, or no. Go; say the woman told me so.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: May I be bold to say so, sir?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Ay, sir; like who more bold?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: I thank your worship. I shall make my master glad with these tidings.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Out alas, sir, cozenage! Mere cozenage.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Where be my horses? Speak well of them, varletto.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Run away with the cozeners; for so soon as I came beyond Eton, they threw me off from behind one of them, in a slough of mire; and set spurs and away, like three German devils, three Doctor Faustuses.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: They are gone but to meet the Duke, villain, do not say they be fled. Germans are honest men.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Hue and cry, villain, go! Assist me, knight, I am undone! Fly, run, hue and cry, villain! I am undone!

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: From the two parties, forsooth.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: The devil take one party and his dam the other! And so they shall be both bestow’d. I have suffer’d more for their sakes—more than the villainous inconstancy of man’s disposition is able to bear.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: And have not they suffer’d? Yes, I warrant; speciously one of them. Mistress Ford, good heart, is beaten black and blue, that you cannot see a white spot about her.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What tellest thou me of black and blue? I was beaten myself into all the colors of the rainbow; and I was like to be apprehended for the witch of Brainford. But that my admirable dexterity of wit, my counterfeiting the action of an old woman, deliver’d me, the knave constable had set me i’ th’ stocks, i’ th’ common stocks, for a witch.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Sir—let me speak with you in your chamber. You shall hear how things go, and, I warrant, to your content. Here is a letter will say somewhat. Good hearts, what ado here is to bring you together! Sure, one of you does not serve heaven well, that you are so cross’d.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Come up into my chamber.

scene.scenelocation: Another room in the Garter Inn.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Prithee no more prattling. Go, I’ll hold. This is the third time; I hope good luck lies in odd numbers. Away, go. They say there is divinity in odd numbers, either in nativity, chance, or death. Away!

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: I’ll provide you a chain, and I’ll do what I can to get you a pair of horns.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Away, I say, time wears, hold up your head and mince.
How now, Master Brook? Master Brook, the matter will be known tonight, or never. Be you in the park about midnight, at Herne’s oak, and you shall see wonders.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Went you not to her yesterday, sir, as you told me you had appointed?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I went to her, Master Brook, as you see, like a poor old man, but I came from her, Master Brook, like a poor old woman. That same knave Ford, her husband, hath the finest mad devil of jealousy in him, Master Brook, that ever govern’d frenzy. I will tell you—he beat me grievously, in the shape of a woman; for in the shape of man, Master Brook, I fear not Goliah with a weaver’s beam, because I know also life is a shuttle. I am in haste, go along with me, I’ll tell you all, Master Brook. Since I pluck’d geese, play’d truant, and whipt top, I knew not what ’twas to be beaten till lately. Follow me, I’ll tell you strange things of this knave Ford, on whom tonight I will be reveng’d, and I will deliver his wife into your hand. Follow. Strange things in hand, Master Brook! Follow.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Master Doctor, my daughter is in green. When you see your time, take her by the hand, away with her to the deanery, and dispatch it quickly. Go before into the park; we two must go together.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: I know vat I have to do. Adieu.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Fare you well, sir.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Trib, trib, fairies; come, and remember your parts. Be pold, I pray you. Follow me into the pit, and when I give the watch-ords, do as I pid you. Come, come, trib, trib.

stagedir.dir: Enter Falstaff with a buck’s head upon him.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Sir John? Art thou there, my deer? My male deer?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My doe with the black scut? Let the sky rain potatoes; let it thunder to the tune of “Green-sleeves,” hail kissing-comfits, and snow eringoes; let there come a tempest of provocation, I will shelter me here.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Mistress Page is come with me, sweet heart.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Divide me like a brib’d-buck, each a haunch. I will keep my sides to myself, my shoulders for the fellow of this walk—and my horns I bequeath your husbands. Am I a woodman, ha? Speak I like Herne the hunter? Why, now is Cupid a child of conscience, he makes restitution. As I am a true spirit, welcome!

stagedir.dir: There is a noise of horns.
They sing a song about him and afterward speak.

scene.line: Lust is but a bloody fire,
Fed in heart, whose flames aspire,
As thoughts do blow them, higher and higher.
Pinch him, and burn him, and turn him about,
Till candles, and starlight, and moonshine be out.

stagedir.dir: Here they pinch him and sing about him. And the Doctor Caius comes one way, and steals away a boy in green; and Slender another way; he takes a boy in white; and Fenton steals Mistress Anne Page. And a noise of hunting is made within; and all the fairies run away. Falstaff pulls off his buck’s head, and rises up.
Enter Page, Ford, Mistress Page, and Mistress Ford.

scene.line: Doctors doubt that. If Anne Page be my daughter, she is, by this, Doctor Caius’ wife.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Vere is Mistress Page? By gar, I am cozen’d. I ha’ married oon garsoon, a boy; oon pesant, by gar. A boy! It is not Anne Page. By gar, I am cozen’d.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Why? Did you take her in green?

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Ay, be-gar, and ’tis a boy. Be-gar, I’ll raise all Windsor.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Pardon, good father! Good my mother, pardon!

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Now, mistress, how chance you went not with Master Slender?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Why went you not with Master Doctor, maid?

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: You do amaze her. Hear the truth of it.
You would have married her most shamefully,
Where there was no proportion held in love.
The truth is, she and I (long since contracted)
Are now so sure that nothing can dissolve us.
Th’ offense is holy that she hath committed,
And this deceit loses the name of craft,
Of disobedience, or unduteous title,
Since therein she doth evitate and shun
A thousand irreligious cursed hours
Which forced marriage would have brought upon her.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Stand not amaz’d; here is no remedy.
In love, the heavens themselves do guide the state;
Money buys lands, and wives are sold by fate.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am glad, though you have ta’en a special stand to strike at me, that your arrow hath glanc’d.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Well, what remedy? Fenton, heaven give thee joy!
What cannot be eschew’d must be embrac’d.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: When night-dogs run, all sorts of deer are chas’d.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Well, I will muse no further. Master Fenton,
Heaven give you many, many merry days!
Good husband, let us every one go home,
And laugh this sport o’er by a country fire—
Sir John and all.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Let it be so. Sir John,
To Master Brook you yet shall hold your word,
For he tonight shall lie with Mistress Ford.
